description: This is a description for the home screen.

events.home_description: Experience Judge Parkers Courtroom, watch the movie, and discover the exhibits.
events.title: Explore the Visitor Center

events.home_description: Walk the grounds with a Park Ranger.  Learn about the evolution of Ft Smith from First Fort to the modern era.
events.title: Schedule a Tour

media.alt: Commissary and supply wagon on a sunny day.

subsections.description: All images featured are provided by the National Park Service (NPS) and National Records and Archives Administration (NARA).
subsections.name: Credits

pages.description: This is the Special Info page!
pages.name: Hiking Info

name: Fort Smith

sites.description: This building has evolved. Beginning in 1838 it was home to the enlisted men as a one-story structure with a basement. In 1872, it was converted to a courthouse and jail. The last major change occurred in 1888 when the second jail was completed. Today it serves as the park Visitor Center.

information.description: A two-story barracks was built in the 1840’s. A fire destroyed most of the building in1849. President Zachary Taylor, who once lived in Fort Smith, did not believe the fort was needed and denied funding to rebuild the barracks causing the fort shut down. After President Taylor, died in 1851 the reconstruction was funded and the fort reopened. In the new building, the living quarters were on the first floor while the dining room was in the basement. In 1871 the military closed the fort for good.

The federal court moved to Fort Smith in 1872. The first story barracks were converted to a courtroom and offices. Over the next 18 years three different judges used this courtroom. Each presided over the largest federal district at the time. Judge William Story resigned instead of being impeached in July, 1874. Judge Caldwell served as the interim judge.  In May of the following year Judge Isaac C Parker began his 21 year tenure. 

Judge Parker used this courtroom until 1890, when a new courthouse was built on the corner of 6th and Rogers. He continued presiding over the court at Fort Smith until his death in 1896. 

Today the courtroom is furnished as it might have been during Judge Parker’s tenure. The exhibits are about Judge Parker and the Federal Court System. The courtroom is used for trial reenactments held several times a year.
information.name: 1872 -1890 Courtroom

information.description:
In 1872, the basement of the courthouse was converted to a jail. Two large cells housed 30-50 men at a time. Prisoners of all ages, accused of both violent and non-violent crimes, were housed together. 

Each cell received little natural light or air. Porches that ran the length of the building shaded the windows. The worst time to be in the jail was during the hot, humid Arkansas summer. Guards threw water across the flagstone floor to “cool” things off. It only added to the humidity. 

Hygiene was poor. One fire place with buckets served as the toilet. The other had a smaller pail for washing. There was no place for a prisoner to bathe. The stench from the jail could be smelled upstairs in the courtroom. Judge Parker had sawdust placed in the rafters to absorb some of the odors. The horrid conditions led to the jail’s nickname, “Hell on the Border.”  

Judge Parker tried repeatedly, with no success to secure funding to build a better jail. Funding did not become available until 1886 when Anna Dawes, daughter of Senator Henry Dawes, wrote an article for a Washington D.C. magazine describing the horrid conditions of the jail.
information.name: Hell on the Border Jail 1872-1888

information.description: The second jail at Fort Smith featured a cell block three tiers high surrounded by an iron cage. Each level held twenty four cells, twelve back-to-back running the length of the building. These measured five feet by seven feet and were furnished with an iron bunk-beds for two prisoners. The inmates relocated here on March 19, 1888. It remained in use until 1917.
information.name: Second Jail 1888-1917

sites.name: Visitor Center
sites.name_description: Park’s Visitor Center, served as a soldiers’ barracks (1838-1871), converted to jail and courthouse in 1872.

sites.description:
Why execution by hanging? At the time, hanging was considered the most humane method of execution. When done properly, the neck is broken and death comes quickly.

Murder, rape, treason, and obstruction of an execution were the only Federal crimes with an automatic death sentence. In Fort Smith, 81 men were hanged for murder and 5 for rape. Crowds in the thousands came to Fort Smith to watch the earlier executions. Then a fence was erected and executions became private two years after Judge Parker arrived. In order to attend an execution, individuals had to get permission from the U.S. Marshal by providing a reason to be there. Those who attended executions included reporters, clergy, medical personnel, and family members of both the victim and the condemned. 

The current gallows are a reproduction based on images and historic records. The original gallows was destroyed by the city of Fort Smith in 1897 because of the negative reputation it gave the city. Today the gallows stand as a stark reminder of the struggle for justice on the western frontier.

information.name: Men Executed at Fort Smith: 1873 to 1896

sites.name: Gallows
sites.name_description: Reproduction built on the location of the original gallows. From 1872 to 1896, 86 men were executed here.

sites.description: The U.S. Government used the Indian Removal Act of 1830 to exchange tribal lands in the east for land west of the Mississippi River. For the Choctaw, Cherokee, Chickasaw, Muscogee (Creek), and Seminole tribes, Indian Removal left a bitter legacy remembered today by some as the Trail of Tears. Each of the five tribes traveled various land and water routes to Indian Territory (today Oklahoma). Some of them stopped at Fort Smith for supplies before continuing to their final destination.
sites.name: Trail of Tears Scenic Overlook
sites.name_description: Scenic view of Arkansas River offering interpretive panels featuring five tribal perspectives of Indian removal.

sites.name: Bass Reeves Statue
sites.name_description: This larger than life bronze statue is dedicated to Deputy US Marshal Bass Reeves and his faithful dog.

sites.name: Miss Laura's Visitor Center
sites.name_description: A former bordello, Fort Smith's official welcome center open Mon.-Sat. from 9 a.m. – 4 p.m. and Sun. 1 p.m. - 4:30 p.m.

sites.name: River Front Park
sites.name_description: Operated by the City of Fort Smith, on the bank of the Arkansas River, the amphitheater hosts concerts and other events.

sites.description:
Soldiers arrived here to begin building the first fort on Christmas Day 1817. Their assignment was to stop the fighting between the long established Osage and the newly arriving Cherokees to Indian Territory. 

Fort Smith was located on the western edge of the United States at that time. Far removed from other towns and supply resources, the first soldiers had to be self-sufficient during long periods of time between supply shipments. Soldiers abandoned the fort and moved deeper into Indian Territory in 1824 and established Fort Gibson.

Here is the first flag to fly over Fort Smith had 15 stars and 15 stripes, one for each state.
sites.name: First Fort Smith
sites.name_description: The first flag to fly over Fort Smith had 15 stars and 15 stripes, one for each state.

sites.description: The quartermaster’s storehouse was built on top of the bastion. Nearby is a survey marker for the Arkansas border.
sites.name: Initial Point Marker and Quartermaster Storehouse
sites.name_description: The quartermaster’s storehouse was built on top of the bastion. Nearby is a survey marker for the Arkansas border.

sites.description: Built by soldiers, the blockhouse was a defensive structure. All that remains is the foundation.
sites.name: Block House of First Fort
sites.name_description: Built by soldiers, the blockhouse was a defensive structure. All that remains is the foundation.

sites.name: Gazebo near First Fort (Includes 3 WS)
sites.name_description: The panels discuss the founding of Fort Smith and those who served here from 1817-1824.

sites.name: Fort Smith National Cemetery
sites.name_description: National Cemetery for veterans from the War of 1812 to present. Open daily 7:30am to sunset.

sites.name: Fort Smith Museum of History (Does this need AD?)
sites.name_description: The museum focuses on the Fort Smith community, includes an operating soda fountain.  Open Tue - Sat 10-5 and Sun 12-5.

sites.name: Second Fort Smith Officers Quarters #1 (includes WS)
sites.name_description: One of two officers quarters constructed and used from 1838-1871. By 1870, chimney fires destroyed both buildings.

sites.name: U.S. Marshall’s Museum Administrative Offices (Does this need AD?)
sites.name_description: Current location of the US Marshal Museum administrative offices, education, and fund-raising activities.

sites.name: Fort Smith Trolley Museum (Does this need AD?)
sites.name_description: Museum dedicated to Fort Smith's early street cars and railroad history. Seasonal hours. Call (479) 783-0205.

sites.name: Defending Freedom (WS)
sites.name_description: During the Civil War, four regiments of United States Colored Troops served in here, including one unit from the city.

sites.name: Fort Wall (WS)
sites.name_description: Originally, the fort was surrounded by a stone wall 12’ high and 2’ feet thick. This fort was one of the last this type.

sites.description:
After the U.S. Army closed Fort Smith in 1871, the federal court converted the guardhouse into a jail for women. If a female prisoner had a child and no family members or friends to take care of the child, he or she went to jail too. During the day, the children were allowed to play on the grounds. We know of at least two children who served time with their mothers. 
Crimes committed by women ranged from the illegal sale of whiskey to murder. When convicted, they received the same sentences as men – fines, jail time, or death by hanging. Although four women were sentenced to hang, none were executed at Fort Smith. 

Constructed in 1849 as the guardhouse, this building served as the initial check-in point for soldiers, supplies, and visitors for the second Fort Smith. It was also the place of confinement for soldiers under arrest for such offenses as drunkenness, desertion, or fighting.
sites.name: Women's Jail
sites.name_description: Guardhouse/jail for 2nd Fort Smith (1838-1871), became the women's jail during Federal Court period (1872-1896).

sites.description: Named for Judge Isaac C. Parker, this building is the current federal courthouse for the Western District of Arkansas.
sites.name: Isaac C. Parker Federal Courthouse
sites.name_description: Named for Judge Isaac C. Parker, this building is the current federal courthouse for the Western District of Arkansas.

sites.name: Gazebo by Parking Lot (includes WS)
sites.name_description: Welcome to Fort Smith National Historic Site, the remains of two military forts and a federal court are preserved here.

sites.name: Frisco Train Depot
sites.name_description: Frisco Train Depot was used from the early 1900s to the mid-1940s.

sites.name: Second Fort Smith Officers Quarters #2
sites.name_description: One of two officers quarters constructed and used from 1838-1871. By 1870, chimney fires destroyed both buildings.

sites.name: Officers' Garden (includes WS)
sites.name_description: The officers' garden is a re-creation of the 1860's garden. The officers’ wives and children cared for the garden.

sites.description:
In 1845, Quartermaster General Thomas Jesup inspected Fort Smith and ordered the fort to be converted into a supply depot. With its new mission, Fort Smith became one of the largest and busiest supply posts in the south. 

The commissary is the oldest building still standing in Fort Smith. Over the years its appearance and use changed.

information.description: From 1875 – 1890, Federal Judge Isaac C. Parker’s office was on the second floor. It is thought that his office was on the north side of the building looking toward the bridge is today.
information.name: Judge Parkers Office

information.description: The Hammersley family used the first floor as their home from 1890-1896.They divided the room to accommodate the family of six. Jacob Hammersley was the Court Crier and his daughter Florence was a Deputy Court Clerk managing paperwork for Judge Parker.
information.name: Home Sweet Home

sites.name: Commissary
sites.name_description: Built in 1846, when the fort’s mission shifted from defensive to a supply depot.

sites.name: Welcome to Fort Smith - Main Entrance (WS)
sites.name_description: Welcome to Fort Smith National Historic Site, the remains of two military forts and a federal court are preserved here.

sites.name: Welcome to Fort Smith - Near Maintenance Building (WS)
sites.name_description: Welcome to Fort Smith National Historic Site, the remains of two military forts and a federal court are preserved here.

sites.name: Whiskey War (WS)
sites.name_description: Soldiers fired a cannon in to the Bigalows tavern after the Bigalows beat-up the fort’s commander.

sites.name: Request Denied (WS)
sites.name_description: In April 1821, 400 Osage warriors attempted to attack Fort Smith, hoping to scare the soldiers.

sites.name: Pioneering Solders (WS)
sites.name_description: Along with their military duties, soldiers were responsible for hunting, gardening, and building the fort.

sites.name: Osage Nation (WS)
sites.name_description: Over 72 years the Osage were forced through treaties to surrender a majority of their homeland.

sites.name: Confederates Occupy (WS)
sites.name_description: On Apr. 22, 1861, Union troops abandoned Fort Smith. Arkansas State Troops took over the fort the next day.

sites.name: Meeting of Nations (WS)
sites.name_description: Treated as the enemy,  12 tribes met with the US Government to agree on post Civil War treaties, which were signed in 1866.

sites.name: Desperate for Survival (WS)
sites.name_description: From 1863-1865, the riverfront landing was often filled with refugees  hoping to escape the devastation of Civil War.

sites.description: From 1846-1871 soldiers performed drill and ceremonies on the parade grounds, making it the center of life at the fort.
sites.name: Parade Ground
sites.name_description: From 1846-1871 soldiers performed drill and ceremonies on the parade grounds, making it the center of life at the fort.

sites.description: A pencil drawing of the first Fort Smith superimposed on a modern picture of the fort’s foundations.
sites.name: Abandoned and Forgotten
sites.name_description: A pencil drawing of the first Fort Smith superimposed on a modern picture of the fort’s foundations.

sites.description:
If you stood here in 1825, on your right would have been Arkansas Territory, and on your left, a vast domain traded to the Choctaw Nation for their ancestral lands in the east.

The Choctaw Treaty of 1825 placed the Indian Territory's Boundary "one hundred paces east of Fort Smith, and running thence, due south, to the Red River." When government surveyors inspected the eastern boundary in 1857, they discovered the original 1825 survey had not run "due south," but slightly southwest. After lengthy deliberation, Federal court officials decided to keep the 1825 boundary and pay the Choctaw Nation $68,102 for the land between the two survey lines.
sites.name: Edge of Indian Territory
sites.name_description: The boundary between Arkansas and Choctaw territory was originally incorrect due to a survey error.

sites.name: Flag Pole (includes Wayside)
sites.name_description: The flagpole (99 ft.) is a reproduction of the original built in 1846. This height allows the flag to be seen for miles.

sites.description: Before running water and indoor plumbing, soldiers dug this cistern in 1869 to collect rainwater.
sites.name: Cistern
sites.name_description: Before running water and indoor plumbing, soldiers dug this cistern in 1869 to collect rainwater.

sites.name: Grave Marker Issac C. Parker
sites.name_description: Located in the Fort Smith National Cemetery, the white headstone is inscribed with just his name and grave number.

sites.name: Bastion #3
sites.name_description: One of five bastions or gun emplacements that would have defended the fort if attacked

sites.name: Grave markers of Major William Bradford and surgeon Thomas Russell (Do these need AD?)
sites.name_description: Fort Smith's earliest grave markers, Major William Bradford, and surgeon Thomas Russell. Both War of 1812 Veterans.
